intro: Abies pinsapo var. glauca, commonly known as the glaucous fir, is a rare and endemic coniferous tree native to the Iberian Peninsula. It is characterized by its bluish-gray foliage, which gives it its common name, and its slender, pyramidal shape. The tree produces cones that are typically 5–7 cm long, containing seeds that are dispersed by wind. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in mountainous regions with well-drained soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
